data.text: The Best Bikepacking Frame: Steel, Carbon, or Titanium?
Steel, Aluminum, Carbon, Titanium? Pros and Cons? Which do you prefer and why? At the end of the day, does it really make that much of a difference?
Steel has been around a long time and it can be fixed almost anywhere in the world if something bad happens.
data.author: Douglas Miner

data.text: In 65 years I‚Äôd biking I‚Äôve only had one frame failure, Carbon. The carbon frame was 20 years old, top tube - seat tube joint.
data.author: Dick Blomshield

data.text: I've never had a failure on aluminum or steel. Carbon or titanium don't fit my budget. I have done a fair amount of welding and brazing so steel is the best choice for me.
data.author: Douglas Miner

data.text: that is about three times longer than carbon frames are supposed to last.
data.author: Timothy Faust

data.text: I have several carbon frames >10 years old without issues. I've had failures on steel (rust) and aluminium (fatigue failure).
data.author: Ivan McAvinchey

data.text: Steel.

data.text: Carbon light and stiff but no good after a big crash, ally not to bad sort of mid ground with strength and weight, steel solid and abit heavy but reliable

data.author: Rick Shaffer

data.author: Garrett W. Smit

data.text: sound advice
data.author: David Riley

data.text: I like steel because I can repair it myself. Titanium is great but too but expensive. I travel too much for Carbon. Aluminum is not my jam, just too much road buzz.
data.author: Alex Helling

data.text: Carbon is the lightest, most efficient, and usually most comfortable. But it's expensive and has an expiration date. Titanium does most of the cool stuff carbon does for even more money, but it lasts forever. Aluminium is cheap and efficient, but ride quality isn't great. You can fix that with nice carbon wheels and running tubeless, but then it isn't cheap anymore. Steel can mean a lot of different things. There is good steel and cheap steel, and everything ok between. Colnago and Walmart both make steel frames, but they are hardly comparable. Steel can have a much more compliant ride than aluminum or titanium, and a good steel frame doesn't weigh much more. But a good steel frame isn't cheap either. A weird property of steel is that it is the least strong material to build a bike out of, but the most durable. Per ounce, steel is about 1/10th as strong as carbon, however a crash that would destroy a carbon frame might just put a solely cosmetic dent in steel. It's also one of the least efficient materials to build a bike out of, but for most people compliance is more important than efficiency.

data.author: Cariad Eira

data.text: The frame material is mostly irrelevant. How it is used and designed is what is important. Even then, your tyre pressure and to a lesser extent your seatpost flex will make more way difference to ride feel - for a rigid bike. As for repairability, how may folk pack welding gear? Because you are unlikely to have a problem handily near a bike repair shop. You can at least carry a kit for emergency fixing carbon frames. But consider this - how often do bike frames actually break outside of racing or being hit by a car?
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: I would say many frames fail just do to long usage Metal fatigues play a big part
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: Do you have actual data on this? In reality most folk don't keep or use bikes long enough for fatigue to be an issue. Which will only be an real problem on metal that flexes, something that bikes are not designed to do.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: , I‚Äôve broken 4 frames.ü§®
data.author: Lee Hollenbeck

data.text: , I asked for data, not anecdotes. üòè
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: Steel of course
data.author: Kieran David Barry

data.text: Anything but aluminum, it's just not a long term metal, and I don't replace bikes very often. The last bike that I replaced, was because my aluminum bike had a catastrophic failure at a weld. I bought a titanium bike to take it's place. Carbon fiber is more susceptible to damage than steel or ti, but it can also be repaired. It's never a good idea to try to repair aluminum, mine was beyond repair. When the weld in the seat tube sheared, the top tube crushed like a beer can near the head tube.
data.author: Matthew Hall

data.text: Titanium will also fail at welds if not made *very* carefully. Had a Ti stem and seatpost, fail for that reason.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: Titanium is great, but I'm gonna go ahead and say it's not worth the money. If I were starting all over, I'd probably get a carbon frame. Expensive, yes, but not as much as titanium. In the past few decades, frame manufacturers have figured out ways to make carbon effectively much stronger and less prone to failure, and a handful of them are making touring-specific carbon frames. Without being the most expensive option, it's the lightest, probably the most aerodynamic, nearly as strong as steel these days, and is as good or better at soaking up road buzz compared to any other material. 2nd choice is steel. Might be the best choice if both you and your gear are heavyweights.
data.author: Rob Landauer

data.text: Oh, I should add, aluminum is a good choice for a bike with suspension. It doesn't matter if the frame isn't compliant, nor the very strongest, when the suspension is soaking up all the bumps. Almost as light as carbon, and significantly cheaper.
data.author: Rob Landauer

data.text: carbon seems to scratch easily, and that diminishes it's structural integrity. If you want something durable that you don't have to baby, something that is smooth to ride and you have the money then I'd go with Titanium. If you can't afford Ti, then tried and true Steel is your friend.

data.text: Carbon all the way

data.text: Having built a steel frame and ti frame, I vote steel. I have a lot more faith my steel frame will last a long time. Maybe after a year or so of riding my Ti frame I'll have more faith in it.

data.text: , I can see how easy it is to mess up a Ti frame. Even experienced builders can mess it up. If your back purge didn't purge properly you might never know until it breaks. Steel is definitely more forgiving when building. As mentioned above, steel could be fixed easier out in the world than the others.

data.text: I'm an aluminum gal, strong and light.

data.text: Jeez so much BS here. Many characteristics of a material can be overcome by design. Carbon doesn't break left right and centre and is actually most easily repairable. Aluminium can be comfortable and also doesn't break left right and centre. Ti can break. Etc

data.text: If there's even a vague chance you'll throw it on the roof of a bus, in the bed of a pick up or poorly packaged in a plane then I wouldn't go Carbon or Aluminium! I've dealt with broken Carbon bars 3 times, broken carbon cranks once and a de-bonded frame. All major brand items! Ive had an aluminium frame badly bent in a plane. Never had any issues with anything steel.

data.text: It is personal preference and what you want from a bike. Better research that for yourself rather than ask people‚Äôs opinions on that subject. üòÇ

data.author: Roman Pertzian

data.text: It doesn't make a difference once you start attaching all the gear to the bike. Aluminum or steel is the way to go....titanium and carbon are too much money. However, if you're racing.....and sponsored or have big money, sure go ahead...gucci it out!
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: I have all three - steel - carbon and Titanium - Each for different purpose. I have a steel Masi fixie great for those quick short trips around town and a ride down to the beach for a swim. A Carbon BMC road when I just want to have a serious workout -and go as fast as I can - just like in my dreams. And there is my Titanium Lynskey for my long bike packing touring trips when I just leave it all behind -the titanium is better on the wear - no paint scratches and just nice to ride where ever the road takes me.

data.text: on the money. I have a Ti gravel bike because it has no paint to chip, and no resin to crack!

data.author: Chris Vela

data.text: This is almost like asking ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs the best seat?‚Äù Very subjective and depends on where/how you ride and your definition of bikepacking. For me, mostly riding gravel and easier trails, with road sections to link them, drop bar steel with 2.2 tires is ideal. Ti would be lighter and more supple, but haven‚Äôt made the plunge (yet). Carbon is great for my full suspension trail bike but too much hassle worrying about protecting it from bag rub for bikepacking. Aluminum stopped being an option in the 90‚Äôs for any bike riding. Too stiff, harsh and prone to cracking. Works great for beer cans.
data.author: Jonathan Robert

data.text: aluminum cracks over time when you ride it. But over thousands of cycles. Not like it just cracks. I mean, the planes you fly in are made of... And a lot of parts on a bike are aluminum still unless you have an all carbon bike. I think most aluminum cracks were on suspension bikes, btw. At the flex zones. How many road bikes have cracked?
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: Btw, I mostly agree with the rest of what you said, and I'm not a fan of aluminum because of its ride quality vs the other materials, but breakage isn't one of its reasons to avoid.

data.author: Jack Driver

data.text: I like them all for one reason or another! They also each have their cons. As long as it's a bike, I don't really care what it's made of as long as I get to ride it!
data.author: Angela M Freeman

data.text: Steel, then titanium. Steel because assuming it's decent quality and made well (and neither is hard to do) it rides nice and will out live you, your grand kids and their childrens children...unless they get hit by anything bigger than a garbage truck. Titanium is a different animal, again, made right and with good tubes, it's a great ride, but lighter and more nimble. Not as forgiving as steel, and not as fixable but less fragile than aluminum (stress cracks) or carbon.
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: , the material is pretty much irrelevant to ride feel compared to seat post design and tyre size/pressures with design and workmanship being key what makes it last. Titanium may be strong, but the welds are the weak point and very hard to do well. Which is part of the reason why good Ti frames are so very expensive. I had a good well made steel frame fail due to corrosion. I lived on sea front, then somewhere with heavily salted roads in winter, so rust weakened frame and it eventually cracked. üôÅ
